content: Anglican bishop (1872–1963) - Christianity portal **Charles James Ferguson-Davie** DD (16 March 1872 – 11 September 1963) was an Anglican bishop, the first [Bishop of Singapore](/wiki/Bishop_of_Singapore), appointed 1910. Born into a clerical family on 16 March 1872 in [Yelverton, Norfolk](/wiki/Yelverton,_Norfolk), Ferguson-Davie was educated at [Marlborough College](/wiki/Marlborough_College) and [Trinity Hall, Cambridge](/wiki/Trinity_Hall,_Cambridge), receiving his B.A. degree in 1894 and M.A. degree in 1899. He attended [Leeds Clergy School](/wiki/Leeds_Clergy_School) and was [ordained](/wiki/Ordained) deacon in 1896 and priest in 1898. His first post was as a [curate](/wiki/Curate) at St Paul, [Preston](/wiki/Preston,_Lancashire). He then became an [USPG](/wiki/USPG) [missionary](/wiki/Missionary). Arriving in the [Punjab Province](/wiki/Punjab_Province_(British_India)) of British India in 1899, Ferguson-Davie served as domestic chaplain to Bishop of Lahore [George Lefroy](/wiki/George_Lefroy) until 1902. He was then assigned to [Rewari](/wiki/Rewari) until 1907 before serving in [Rawalpindi](/wiki/Rawalpindi) until 1909. Ferguson-Davie served as the first bishop of the [Anglican Diocese of Singapore](/wiki/Anglican_Diocese_of_Singapore_(1909)) from 1909 to 1927. He was conferred an honorary D.D. degree by the University of Cambridge in 1909. In later life, Ferguson-Davie was also a [Priest](/wiki/Priest) and [Warden](/wiki/Churchwarden) in [Natal](/wiki/Natal_Province). When he died on 11 September 1963 in [Pietermaritzburg](/wiki/Pietermaritzburg), he was the [Church](/wiki/Anglican_Church)’s most senior bishop, having been [consecrated](/wiki/Consecrated) 54 years earlier on 24 August 1909 in [St. Paul's Cathedral](/wiki/St._Paul%27s_Cathedral), London. ## Personal life His paternal grandfather was [Henry Ferguson Davie](/wiki/Henry_Ferguson_Davie). In 1902, he married [Charlotte Elizabeth Hull](/wiki/Charlotte_Ferguson-Davie), a physician working in a British mission hospital. They adopted a daughter. After his wife's death in 1943, he remarried with Marie Antoinette Jacobine (Hax) Randles, the widow of a South African barrister, in 1948.
